comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: White haired gentleman with the mustache in front looks like E. Walsh, the mayor in 1928-29. So the guy wearing the chain of office may be William Jones, mayor 1930-31.

comment.author: 67700841@N06
comment._content: The gentleman on top row, 2nd from left, with moustache, is Austin Farrell, General Manager and Secretary Waterford Harbour Commissioners. He was my great uncle.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/67700841@N06] Thank you so much for this fantastic information! Could this be your great uncle when he was younger?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 67700841@N06
comment._content:
Yes, this is Austin Farrell, brother of my grandfather, Walter J. farrell, Harbour Master Waterford 1903 to 1940.

Austin Aaron Farrell, born 22nd February 1872, died 28th February 1934. He was married 26th October 1897 at St. Mary's Clonmel, to Gertrude Josephine O'Mahony daughter of Denis Patrick O'Mahoney of 1 Anne Street Clonmel (Corn Merchant), and Mary Ronan Shandon House , Dungarvan, Co. Waterford. He was Secretary and General manager of Waterford Harbour Commissioners. Austin Farrell died 28th February 1934 at Summerville House Waterford and is buried in Ballygunner Cemetery, Waterford.

Brendan Grogan

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/67700841@N06] Brilliant! Thanks very much for coming back to us so quickly - and with such detailed information... If you know anyone who might have information about any of the other men, please feel free to spread the word!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 38524172@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Yes, (belated response) this is the same gentleman with my mother's auntie Gertie...

comment.author: 87679361@N07
comment._content: I believe the gentleman front row, second from right, is my grandfather Michael Archdale Morris who owned the Samuel Morris business. (Incidentally, The Chamber of Commerce building was a Morris residence until 1816)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/87679361@N07] Thank you very much! Have added a note on your grandfather in the photo.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
